awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Integrating Culturally Relevant Project-based AI Learning into High School STEM Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The exponential expansion of artificial intelligence (AI) has created a significant demand on future AI workforce development.  Several key challenges exist hindering the widespread incorporation of AI into K-12 curricula, including the lack of teacher development in AI and a comprehensive pedagogical framework for K-12 AI education. This project aims to engage high-school students from North Dakota and southern Alabama, two geographical areas with large populations from historically marginalized groups, in the learning of AI by implementing and examining a culturally relevant project-based AI-integrated learning framework.  The framework connects AI learning with students' learning experiences in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) classes, fostering the growth of their interdisciplinary problem-solving skills.  To develop students' individual interest in AI, their learning is situated within the context of personal experiences. This proposal was received in response to the Dear Colleague Letter (DCL): Rapidly Accelerating Research on Artificial Intelligence in K-12 Education in Formal and Informal Settings (NSF 23-097) and funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers.

The project includes two components: (1) training of high-school teachers, and (2) teachers' classroom implementation. Seventeen teachers will participate in small group and individual hands-on practices, immersive workshops, reflection and discussion, and presentations. Researchers will carry out mixed-method design research examining teacher training outcome. With scaffolding and support from researchers, teachers will develop and teach AI-STEM integrated lessons in biology and pre-calculus at their own high schools in North Dakota and southern Alabama. Multimodal data collection and analysis will be used for researching the perceptual, cognitive, and kinesthetic processes about students' problem-solving skills, interdisciplinary knowledge use, and classroom participation, as well as how these processes affect students' STEM and AI learning and interest development. This research has significant potential to contribute to our knowledge on how to effectively support historically marginalized students' interest in and learning of AI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we implemented and examined a Culturally Relevant Project-based AI-integrated Learning (CRPAIL) framework to improve high-school STEM students’ learning and interest in AI in southern Alabama (AL) and North Dakota (ND). The goals of this project were 1) to develop high-school teachers’ knowledge of using the CRPAIL framework to teach AI-integrated STEM subjects, and 2) to improve high-school students’ interest in AI and learning of AI and STEM subjects in CRPAIL lessons.

Seventeen teachers were recruited and participated in this project. Most of them were from Title 1 schools or schools from rural areas. They participated in a 4-week professional development (PD) program, aiming to develop their’ AI knowledge as well as skills of integrating AI into their subject courses using culturally relevant project-based learning. Following the PD program, they taught integrated AI lessons in their high-school STEM subjects.

Intellectual Merit

This project advanced the knowledge of teaching teachers to integrate AI in their STEM subject teaching using the pedagogy of culturally relevant project-based learning. Key accomplishments include:

Development of the CRPAIL PD framework: Our study found that the PD program that incorporated hands-on practices, peer discussions and exchanges, and culturally relevant project-based learning workshops successfully improved teachers’ AI knowledge, knowledge of teaching a subject content using appropriate technology and pedagogy (TPACK), and culturally relevant teaching self-efficacy. While the PD program improved these competencies, we observed that teachers’ classroom implementations varied and were related to their knowledge developed during the PD program. The findings highlighted the areas to refine the existing CRPAIL PD framework, such as offering more personalized support to address teachers’ individual needs.

Students’ improved knowledge and positive Interest in AI: Students in the participating teachers' classes learned AI knowledge and its applications or connections with their subject topics. In addition, they gained exposure to current AI applications in research and industry through their teachers' shared experiences and field trips. Results of our analysis showed significant improvements in students’ AI and subject knowledge. By enabling students to view AI learning through an interdisciplinary or cross-disciplinary lens, the integrated AI lessons mirrored the complexity of real-world challenges and fostered a deeper understanding of AI's role in various domains. In the post-lesson surveys, students responded positively toward the integrated AI lessons as well as their interest in AI. Furthermore, their written reflections highlighted the positive impact of culturally relevant project-based learning and the interdisciplinary curriculum on sustaining their interest and curiosity, which was also supported by the results of our analysis on students’ conversations in the lessons.

Broader Impact

More inclusive and diverse learning environment: Participating teachers in this project brought students’ real-world experiences, such as agriculture and fishing, into the classroom by using the culturally relevant project-based learning approach. It ensured that the curriculum was inclusive and responsive to the diverse backgrounds and experiences of the students, promoting a sense of belonging and engagement.

This project generated two conference papers and one journal manuscript. Two conference papers were accepted by the 2025 AERA and SIGCSE conferences. One journal manuscript is currently under review.

Findings of this project were shared at two local workshops for in-service teachers. One workshop titled “Integrating AI in K-12 STEM Learning” was delivered in June 2024. The other workshop titled “Integrating AI Literacy Education in STEM Education” took place in July 2024. Both workshops introduced the fundamental concepts of AI and machine learning. Teachers who taught the integrated AI curriculum shared their lessons and experiences with participants.
